I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the People's Republic of China (PRC) had requested the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) in 2001 to assist the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) in improving 
statistics in the services sector. Accordingly, ADB agreed to include a provision for advisory 
technical assistance (TA) in its 2002 Country Strategy Program (CSP).  
 
2.  A Fact-Finding Mission visited Beijing from 9 to 13 September 2002 to discuss the 
nature,  scope,  and  implementation  arrangements  as  well  as  other  issues  relating  to  the 
proposed  TA.  During  the  visit,  the  Mission  had  extensive  discussions  with  the  concerned 
officials of the various government agencies as well as with the representatives of international 
agencies that had supported the development of statistics in the PRC. After discussions and 
consultations with the senior officials of NBS, and other government and international agencies, 
understanding  was  reached  on  the  objective,  scope,  financing,  and  implementation 
arrangements of the proposed TA.1 The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  During  the  last  several  years,  the  PRC  has  made  substantial  progress in  national 
accounting estimation, including the implementation of the 1993 Systems of National Accounts 
(SNA  1993).  Some  recent  milestones  are  the  introduction  of  estimates  of  gross  domestic 
product (GDP) by expenditure category, production of quarterly national accounts by industry, 
and review and revision of the GDP series. However, PRC statistics still suffer from a number of 
serious limitations, including those that are due to data coverage and methodological issues. 
NBS is aware of these limitations and  is fully committed to resolving them over time. Efforts 
have been made to expand the coverage of the data sources and refine the methodologies. 
 
4.  In the PRC's statistical reporting system, data are collected at the village, city, county, 
and province levels. Aggregate data are then passed upward to NBS through the provincial 
governments. This practice reduces the ability of NBS to check the data and change methods, 
precludes seasonal adjustments, restricts the possibilities for comparing different periods, and 
delays the identification of turning points. The lack of separation of government and statistical 
functions at the local level gives some provinces the opportunity to misreport data so as to 
appear more progressive and profitable. Consequently, the perception among some foreign 
commentators is that some numbers published by NBS could be overestimated. 
 
5.  Recent Government reforms have resulted in rapid expansion of the services sector 
activities.  This  expansion  has  contributed  to  the  rapid  development  of  information  and 
communication technology (ICT) services including software, growth of financial and banking 
sector activities, expansion of the real estate sector in both urban and rural areas, rapid 
increase of informal sector activities, expansion of environmental and tourism services, etc. 
Globalization  has  also  had  a  direct  impact  on  trade  and  communications  services.  The 
expansion and improvements in services will result in a higher economic share for the sector in 
terms of investments and output. Current official estimates of the output and value added of the 
services  sector  do  not  reflect  the  rapid  expansion  of  the  services  industry  and  may  be  a 
significant underestimation. This underestimation, which is due to incomplete coverage and 
underpricing of services such as housing, public schools, and public transportation, has been a 
major problem in estimating of GDP in the PRC.

2 
6.  Discussions of issues on services sector statistics differentiate two broad classes of 
services.  Consumer  services  are  those  provided  to  individuals  and  households  for  final 
consumption. Examples are haircuts, medical treatment, entertainment, and security. Producer 
services are intermediate inputs that are embodied in the production of other goods and 
services. Examples are those in advertising, marketing (wholesale and retail), transport of soft 
drinks or motorcycles, etc. Some problems that arise in identifying and measuring the output of 
services under the current statistical systems of the PRC are worth highlighting. First, the 
production-based  method  of  national  accounts  identifies  sectors  as  "goods  producing"  or 
"services producing." However, a sizable part of value added that is attributed to the former 
sector consists of services. There is, therefore, a systematic undervaluation bias against the 
services sector output. This is true, especially for sectors producing services. Second, it is often 
difficult  to  distinguish  between  consumer  and  producer  services,  a  fact  that  adds  to  the 
undervaluation bias in measuring the latter. The output of "services producing" sectors may be 
both for final consumption and an intermediate input into a production process. This is easy to 
see for such subsectors as finance, insurance, transport, and real estate. It is also true of other 
services-producing subsectors, such as restaurants and a wide range of services delivered by 
the Government. 
 
7.  One International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) study,2 gives 
four main reasons why the statistical system underestimates the size of the services sector in 
the  PRC.  First,  the  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  traditionally  provided  "cradle-to-grave" 
services to their employees, but began to shed the extended social services recently. Such a 
degree of vertical integration between production and services naturally lowered the demand for 
external  services.  Second,  the  nominal  value  of  agriculture  and  industrial  output  is  often 
overestimated, resulting in an under-estimation of the share of services in the national economy. 
The  gross  industrial  output  of  the  township  and  village  enterprises,  in  particular,  is 
overestimated despite the efforts of NBS to correct it. Third, agricultural and industrial output is 
relatively underdeflated compared with the services output; the result is an upward bias in 
measuring  the  real  value  of  agricultural  and  industrial  output,  compounding  the  problems 
created by overestimation of their nominal values. Fourth, for a long time the statistical system 
ignored services, using instead standard socialist-planned economy accounting methodologies 
adopted  from  the  Soviet  model.  NBS  has  corrected  some  of  the  statistical  biases  against 
services by conducting the Census of the Tertiary Sector during 1993-1995, but much work is 
yet to be undertaken. 
 
8.  The census was the first extensive survey of the services sector in the PRC. It resulted 
in significant revisions to the value added in service activities and in GDP. But since then, there 
has been no significant effort to collect information even for major services sector activities. The 
growing importance of the services industry in the PRC has raised the need to survey and 
measure  the  contribution  of  these  activities,  covering  the  tertiary  sectors  including 
transportation, storage and communication, wholesale and retail trade, banks and nonbanks, 
real  estate  and  ownership  of  one's  own  dwelling  account  (housing  services),  private  and 
government  services  ICT  services,  including  e-commerce,  are  already  changing  the 
characteristics of trade, communication, business services, and other sectors. These services 
sector activities are undergoing structural changes that will have an impact on their share of the 
national  income.  Statistical  measurements  in  the  services  industry  must  take  these  new 
developments  into  account,  to  make  the  role  of  the  private  sector  more  transparent  and 
effective, and to facilitate good governance and monitoring of the economy. The statistical

system of the PRC should develop new methods of measuring and collecting data to capture 
the changes. 
 
9.  There are major problems in measuring informal sector activities. Most small businesses 
are not adequately covered in enterprise surveys. The emergence of private firms (i.e., private 
schools, private banking and nonbanking financial institutions, security companies, legal firms, 
internet providers) has complicated the measurement issues. Although household surveys are 
conducted in both rural and urban areas, no information is collected from family-owned and -
operated small businesses except farms. Thus, there are major data gaps in informal sector 
activities. Sample surveys for small enterprises (eight or more workers) are conducted by the 
Enterprise Survey Organization and the Department of Trade and External Relations Statistics 
on an ad hoc basis, but there is a whole range of small firms that have not been covered in 
sample  surveys  conducted  by  NBS.  NBS  should  improve  the  estimates  of  informal  sector 
activities,  especially  those  relating  to  enterprises  employing  less  than  eight  persons  and 
households not covered by NBS sample surveys. 
 
10.  The  demand  for  better  statistics  in  the  services  sector  of  the  economy  has  been 
increasing, particularly from the private sector. NBS has not been able to effectively meet that 
demand and needs to strengthen its capability for improving the services sector statistics. 
Strengthening NBS will help improve the estimation of national accounts and bring that function 
in line with international standards. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The TA aims to strengthen the national account estimates of the PRC, with special 
emphasis on improving services sector statistics. To achieve this objective, the TA will support 
NBS to  (i) develop suitable methodologies for measuring output and value added of services, 
particularly in sectors that are growing rapidly; (ii) implement these methodologies in a pilot 
survey; (iii) adapt the tested methodology in nationwide surveys; (iv) revise national accounts 
estimates on the basis of survey findings; and (v) upgrade the skills of the staff of the National 
Accounts Department (NAD) of NBS and provincial staff in collecting and compiling services 
sector statistics and in reviewing and revising national accounts estimates.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will be implemented in coordination with all international agencies active in 
providing assistance for improving statistical services in the PRC, especially the Organization 
for Economic Co-operation  and  Development  (OECD),  World  Bank,  International  Monetary 
Fund (IMF), Statistics Canada, United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and Economic 
and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP). Coordination will be necessary to 
avoid duplication as well as to learn from each other's experiences. These agencies will also be 
invited to attend the TA workshops and share their knowledge and experiences with various 
issues and methodologies relating to the measurement of statistics in the services sector. The 
Government will support the TA by giving priority to improving the technical capacity of the 
provincial and local staff, and commercializing and publishing of the data through the NBS web 
site. 
 
13.  The TA will comprise the following activities

4 
(i)  Provide international and domestic consultants to help NBS identify data gaps 
and sources of data, develop methodologies, and prepare manuals/handbooks to 
help the NBS staff in collecting and compiling services sector statistics;  
 
(ii)  Offer apprenticeship programs for NBS staff to learn from the experiences of 
statistically more developed countries, preferably OECD member countries;  
 
(iii)  Help  NBS  organize  a  short-term  training  program  in  services  statistics  for 
provincial staff to enhance their technical skills;  
 
(iv)  Provide necessary computers and related equipment for the National Accounts 
Department of NBS; and  
 
(v)  Provide partial support to implement a survey on the services sector in one 
province on a pilot basis to test the methodologies developed during the project 
period, and help adapt this tested methodology nationwide on a regular basis.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000 equivalent, of which $280,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $470,000 is the local currency cost (Appendix 2). The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $450,000 equivalent covering the entire foreign exchange cost, 
and $170,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the 
balance of the local currency cost equivalent to $300,000, through the provision of counterpart 
salary,  survey  operations,  accommodations,  office  space,  and  other  miscellaneous  local 
expenses.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 3 years beginning in July 2003 and will be completed 
in June 2006. NBS  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  The  Development  Indicators  and  Policy 
Research Division (ERDI) of ADB will administer the TA. NBS will appoint the director general of 
NAD of NBS as project director who will be responsible for coordinating with ADB, for day-to-
day project implementation, disbursement of funds, supervision of the work of consultants, and 
reviewing their reports. 
 
16.  The TA will finance the services of 9 person-months of international consultants (person-
months in parenthesis): lead institutional sector consultant (4), corporate sector consultant (2.5) 
and non-corporate sector consultant (2.5); and domestic consultants for 21 person-months: 
government services sector (5), financial corporate services sector (4), non-financial corporate 
services (7), and household services sector (5). In addition, the TA will fund the participation of 
an expert from OECD in implementing activities, as and when needed as OECD has long 
experience working with NBS in the area of national accounts and services sector statistics. The 
consultants  will  be  recruited  individually  according  to  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting and engaging domestic 
consultants. The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  The  TA  funds  will  be  disbursed  to  NBS  in  accordance  with  the  procedures  and 
requirements of ADB's advance payment facility.

5 
18.  The TA will support both local and international training of NAD and provincial staff. Two 
NAD staff will participate in an apprenticeship program to the national statistical office of a 
developed OECD country in the region for about 2 months to gain practical experience in 
collecting and compiling of services sector statistics. The TA will also finance in-country training 
courses for statistical staff of NBS and other line ministries, and provincial and local offices. The 
Government will provide the necessary staff and space for the training courses. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People's Republic of China for Improving Services Sector Statistics, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   International Consultants  
 
1.   Institutional Sector Lead Consultant (4 person-months)  
 
1.  The institutional sector lead consultant will have appropriate qualifications and technical 
background  or  experience  in  designing  service-related  enterprise  surveys.  The  expert  will 
perform these tasks:  
 
(i)  Lead a team of international consultants and domestic experts in helping the 
National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) of the People's Republic of China (PRC) 
implement  the  technical  assistance  for  improving  services  sector  statistics, 
coordinate the assignments of individual consultants, and provide guidance as 
necessary.  
 
(ii)  Review services sector statistics, identify data gaps in the statistics, and propose 
a methodology for measuring the output and value added as well as for collecting 
data in the services sector.  
 
(iii)  Hold  consultations  with  the  appropriate  staff  of  the  Department  of  National 
Accounts (DNA) on the proposed methodology, and finalize the methodology on 
the basis of these consultations.  
 
(iv)  In coordination with the other international and domestic consultants, help NBS in 
(a) conducting a pilot survey on the basis of assessments described in (ii) and (b) 
testing the methodologies developed for measuring the output and value added 
of the services sector.  
 
(v)  Review the results of the pilot survey in cooperation with the staff of DNA. On the 
basis of the review, finalize the methodology to be adapted nationally.  
 
(vi)  Review  and  comment  on  the  manuals  and  handbooks  prepared  by  other 
international and domestic consultants.  
 
(vii)  Submit a completion report to NBS and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) at 
the end of each engagement.  
 
2.   Corporate Sector Consultant (2.5 person- months)  
 
2.  The corporate sector consultant will have a strong background and experience in the 
field of services sector statistics, preferably in both financial and nonfinancial corporate sectors. 
The expert will perform these tasks:  
 
(i)  In  consultation  with  the  lead  consultant  and  domestic  experts,  review  the 
services statistics in the PRC, particularly those relating to the financial and 
nonfinancial sectors, identify data gaps and data weaknesses in these sectors, 
and propose a methodology for measuring the output and value added as well as 
for collecting data.

(ii)  Provide necessary guidelines to the domestic experts in preparing the manuals 
and handbooks necessary for collecting data in these areas.  
 
(iii)  Hold  consultations  with  the  concerned  DNA  staff,  the  lead  consultant,  and 
domestic experts, as necessary, on the proposed methodology, and finalize it on 
the basis of the consultations.  
 
(iv)  Review the manuals and handbooks and help the domestic consultants improve 
and finalize the materials.  
 
(v)  Submit  a  completion  report  to  NBS  and  ADB  3  days  from  the  end of each 
engagement.  
 
3.   Noncorporate Sector Consultant (2.5 person-months)  
 
3.  The noncorporate sector consultant must have a strong background and experience in 
the  field  of  services  sector  statistics,  preferably  in  the  government,  rest  of  the  world, and 
households sectors. The expert will perform these tasks:  
 
(i)  In  consultation  with  the  lead  consultant  and  domestic  experts,  review  the 
services sector statistics in the PRC, particularly those relating to government, 
rest of the world, and households,  identify data gaps and data weaknesses in 
those  sectors;  and  propose  a  methodology  for  measuring  output  and  value 
added as well as for collecting data.  
 
(ii)  Provide necessary guidelines to the domestic experts for preparing the manuals 
and handbooks as necessary for collecting data in these areas.  
 
(iii)  Hold  consultations  with  the  concerned  DNA  staff,  the  lead  consultant,  and 
domestic  experts  as  necessary  on  the  proposed  strategy,  and  finalize  the 
strategy on the basis of these consultations.  
 
(iv)  Review the manuals and handbooks prepared by the domestic consultants, and 
help the domestic consultants improve and finalize the materials.  
 
(v)  Submit a completion report to NBS and  ADB at the end of each assignment.  
 
B.   Domestic Consultants  
 
1.   Government Services Sector Expert (5 person-months)  
 
4.  The  government  services  sector  expert  must  have  appropriate  qualifications  and 
technical background or experience in designing and implementing service-related enterprise 
surveys. Under the overall guidance of the lead institutional service sector consultant, this 
expert will perform these specific tasks:  
 
(i)  Help  the  institutional  sector  lead  consultant  and  corporate  sector  consultant 
review the services sector statistics relating to the government and the rest of the 
world,  identify  data  gaps  and  weaknesses,  and  develop  a  methodology  for 
improving statistics relating to those sectors.

2.   Financial Corporate Services Sector Expert (4 person-months) 
 
5.  The financial corporate services sector expert must have appropriate qualifications and 
technical background or experience in designing and implementing surveys of service-related 
enterprises.  The  expert  will  be  working  under  the  guidance  of  the  institutional  sector  lead 
consultant and will perform these specific tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist the institutional sector and corporate services consultants in reviewing the 
services statistics related to the financial corporate sector, identify data gaps and

(ii)  Prepare a draft manual to help statisticians/national accountants collect services 
statistics related to the sector. 
 
(iii)  Help the international consultants organize and conduct workshops, and prepare

methodology  in  a  pilot  survey;  and  help  NBS  in  adapting  the  methodology

(iv)  Submit a completion report to the ADB and NBS at the end of each assignment. 
 
3.  Nonfinancial Corporate Services Sector Expert (7 person-months)  
 
6.  The nonfinancial corporate services sector expert must have appropriate qualifications 
and technical background or experience in designing and implementing surveys service-related 
enterprises, particularly for the nonfinancial corporate sector such as social services industry 
and new types of service activities. The expert will work under the guidance of the institutional 
sector lead consultant and perform these specific tasks:  
 
(i)  Help the institutional sector lead consultant review services statistics relating to 
the nonfinancial corporate services sector, identify data gaps and weaknesses, 
and develop a methodology for improving statistics relating to the sector.  
 
(ii)  Prepare draft manuals to help statisticians/national accountants collect services 
statistics relating to this sector.  
 
(iii)  Help the international consultants (a) organize and conduct the workshops and 
prepare  necessary  documentation  for  the  workshops;  (b)  test  the  developed 
methodology  through  a  pilot  survey;  and  (c)  help  NBS  in  adapting  the 
methodology nationally.

4.   Household Services Sector Expert (5 person-months)  
 
7.  The household services sector expert must have appropriate qualifications and technical 
background or experience in designing and implementing services sector surveys, particularly 
for household services. The expert will be working under the guidance of the lead consultant 
and will perform these specific tasks:  
 
(i)  Help the lead consultant and the noncorporate sector consultant review services

(ii)  Prepare  a  draft  manual  to  help  statisticians  and  national  accountants  collect

(iii)  Help the international consultants  (a) organize/conduct workshops and prepare 
the  necessary  documentation  for  the  workshops;  (b)  test  the  developed 
methodology  through  a  pilot  survey;  and  (c)  help  NBS  in  adapting  the 
methodologies nationally.  
 
(iv)  Submit a completion report to the ADB and NBS 3 days before the end of each
